title.content: How did miners die in the Universal Colliery and whose fault was it?

clue1.content: The Universal mine was the biggest employer in Senghenydd.

clue2.content: The kind of coal mined at the pit contained a lot of firedamp – explosive methane gas. There was also a lot of coal dust in the mine which could also explode.

clue3.content: Before the Universal colliery was built, Senghenydd had a population of less than 100. In 1913 there were more than 6000 people living there.

clue4.content: The miners there dislike William Lewis due to his history of poor treatment to staff.

clue5.content: The miners there dislike William Lewis due to his history of poor treatment to staff.

clue6.content: The disaster started at 8.10 am. An electrical spark from electrical equipment ignited the firedamp.

clue7.content: The explosions were so violent that the cage of the Lancaster shaft was blown back up to wedge in the pithead winding gear. Someone standing close by was decapitated by a piece of flying wood.

clue8.content: Miners breathing afterdamp suffocated for lack of oxygen despite not being hurt by the explosion.

clue9.content: 935 miners were down the pit on Tuesday 14th October 1913.

clue10.content: Edward Shaw, the manager, blamed the designers of the mine. He said the intake airway acted as a fan to the flames.

clue11.content: In 1914 a court case found that William Lewis should pay 25 pounds in fines for the disaster.

clue12.content: Lewis blamed the site manager Edward Shaw for the disaster due to the electrical fault.

clue13.content: In 1864 William Lewis marries Anne Rees and becomes wealthy.

clue14.content: The shock wave from the firedamp explosion caused coal dust to rise into the air which also ignited.

clue15.content: 1896 William Lewis opens the Universal Colliery in Senghenydd.

clue16.content: The fires spread through most of the underground workings, quickly followed by afterdamp – poisonous gasses from the explosion like carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide.

clue17.content: In 1901 an explosion at the mine killed 81 people. Safety issues were brought up and coal dust was supposed to be removed.

clue18.content: Rescue teams rushed to the scene were hampered by fallen debris, roof falls and raging fires.

clue19.content: Edward Shaw and William Lewis did not follow the safety recommendations of the 1901 report and there was still coal dust in the mine.

clue21.content: Miners got paid less because the price of coal was low so they had to work harder.

clue22.content: By 1913 William Lewis was in his 70 and visited his Senghenydd coal mine less and less.
